results.name: Largest prime factor of the integer formed by truncating the decimal expansion of Pi to n places.
link: Robert G. Wilson v, Table of n, a(n) for n = 0..169 (first 101 terms from Ryan Moore)
I. O. Angell, and H. J. Godwin, On Truncatable Primes Math. Comput. 31, 265-267, 1977.
Hisanori Mishima, Decimal expansions of π (n = 0 to 100)
Hisanori Mishima, Decimal expansions of π (n = 101 to 200)
Hisanori Mishima, Decimal expansions of π (n = 201 to 250)
Index entries for sequences related to truncatable primes
formula: a(n) = A011545(n) iff n is a term in A060421. - _Robert G. Wilson v_, May 30 2015
mathematica: f[n_] := FactorInteger[ IntegerPart[ Pi*10^(n - 1)]][[-1, 1]]; Array[f, 23] (* _Robert G. Wilson v_, May 30 2015 *)
results.author: _Jason Earls_, Dec 09 2002
